TEI:
&teiHeader; &facsimile;
49 Vita sancti Kenelmi. Regis.
SEint Kenelm, þe &yogh;ongue kyng : þat holi martyr is,
he was kyng in Engelonde : of þe Marche of Walis.
Kyng kenulf his fader hiet : he was kyng þare also;
Þe Abbeie of wynchecoumbe he liet arere : And þare-inne monekes do;
And Aftur is deþe he was þare i-bured : and &yogh;eot he lijth þere
In þe Abbei&yogh;e, þat &yogh;eot stant : þat he him-seolf liet a-rere.
Þo was wynchecombe gret cite : and mest of i-nov&yogh;
Of al þulke half of Engelonde : so feor so his lond drou&yogh;.
Fyf kingues þare weren þulke tyme : In engelonde i-do,
For Enguelond was guod and long : and sum-del brod al-so.
A-bouten ei&yogh;te hondret mile : Engelond long is
Fram[MS. fran] þe South into þe North : and to houndret brod i-wis
Fram þe Est into þe West. : al-so þare-inne beoth
Manie wateres guode i-nowe : þat men al dai i-seoth.
bote þreo wateres principales : of alle ne beoth, i-wis :
Þat .on. is homber, þat oþur seuerne : and temes þe þridde is.
To þe North-se hombur geth : þat is on of þe beste,
And Temese into þe est-se : and seuerne into þe weste.
¶ Þeos fijf kyngus of Engelonde : þat weren bi olde dawe,
hadden heore part ech bi him-seolf i-deld : ase it was ri&yogh;t and lawe.
Þe kyng þat was of þe March : he hadde al þat beste :
Muche del he hadde of Engelond : þat on half al-bi weste,
Wyrecestre-schire, and ware-wike-schire : and þe schire of gloucestre—
Þat is nei&yogh;wat al o bischopriche : þe bischopes of wyrecestre.
he hadde þar-to chastre-schire : and derbi-schire al-so,
And stafford-schire—þat beoth alle : to[al. in] one bischope-riche i-do,
In þe bischop-riche of Chastre : and &yogh;eot heo beoth þar-to,
Schrobbe-schire sum : and warewyke-schire haluen-del al-so.
Þis king hadde al-so hereforde-schire : þat o bischopriche is,
Ake Schrob-schire fallez haluendel : to þulke schire,[al. bischopriche] i-wis,
And sum of warewike-schire : and of gloucestre-schire al-so.
Sethþe hadde þe king of þe March : wel more lond þer-to :
Nore-hampte-schire, and boking-ham-schire : and þe schire of Oxen|ford,
Leycestre-schire, . lincolne-schire : and þe schire of hert-ford—
Þat is al o bischopriche : þat of lincolne nouþe is,
Þat &yogh;wuylene was of deorkcestre : bi-side Oxenforde, i-wis.
Sethþe hadde þe king of þe March : Notingham-schire þer-to—
In þe bischopriche of Euerwike : bote þo nas it nou&yogh;t so.
Þo was al þis lond i-cleoped : þe Marche of Walis :
Of al þis seint kenelmes fader : he was king, i-wis.
Non of alle þe oþere kyne-riches : a-&yogh;ein þis kinedom nas;
And wynche-coumbe of al þis lond : chef Cite þo was.
Þis fijf kyngues þat weren þo : þat on was of kent, i-wis,
And þe oþer, ase ich ou seide er : of þe Marche of walis,
Of Esex,[r. Westsex] and of North-homberlond : and of est-lond al-so—
Þis fijf kynedomes in engelond : in þat time weren i-do.
Þe king of west-sex hadde þo : al wilte-schire, i-wis,
And Deorkecestre,[al. Dorsete] and barroke-schire : þat al o bischopriche is,
To[al. om.] þe bischopriche of salesburi— : ake þo nas it so nou&yogh;t,[orig. nou&yogh;t so]
For þe chief stude of þe bischopriche : at schirbourne was i-wrou&yogh;t.
Sethþe hadde þe kyng of west-sex : south-sex al-so,
Þe welde and al þe bischopriche : of Cicestre þer-to;
And southampte-schire and soþereye : þat of þe[r. o] bischopriche is,
Þe bischopriche of wynchestre : þat &yogh;uyt is þere, i-wis;
And somer-sete [þat] to welles : þulke tyme drou&yogh;—
Nov it is þe bischopriche of baþe : &yogh;e schullen i-wyten.[al. &yogh;e witeþ wel inou&yogh;][vv. 63-4 are transp. in the MS.]
¶ Þe kyng of west-sex hadde sethþe : al deuene-schire, i-wis,
And Cornwaile, þat in þe bischopriche : of Eccestre nouþe is.—
Þe king of kent was þo kyng : of al þe londe of kent,
Þat weren inne tweie bischopriches : and &yogh;eot nis it nou&yogh;t i-went :
Þe bischopriche of Caunterburi : þat in Engelonde &yogh;eot is hext,
And þe bischopriche of Roucestre : þat inþe west-side is next.—
Þe king þat was of ast-londe : king was of North-folk,
Þe bischopriche of Northwich : and al-so of south-folk
And al þe bischopriche of hely : þat þe Yle of hely &yogh;eot is,
And grauntebrugge-schire : þare-to fallez, i-wis;
Seint Eadmund was of þat lond : kyng bi olde dawe—
For he was in is owene lond : for is guodnesse a-slawe.—
Þe kyng of North-humber-lond : was kyng, ich onder-stonde,
Of al þe londe bi-&yogh;eonde houmber : A-non into scotlonde,
Þe bischopriche of Eouerwik : and of Duyrham, i-wis;
Seint Oswold bi olde dawe : was kyng of al þis.
Þus manie kyngues weren : &yogh;wylene in Engelonde,
And heore londes de-partede weren : þus, ich under-stonde.—
Þe kyng þat was of þe march : ase ich telle bi-gan,
Kenulf kyng he was i-cleoped : swiþe holi and guod man :
Seint kenelm was is sone : and is eir al-so;
Borewenild and quendrith : weren is dou&yogh;trene two.
In þe foure-and-twentiþe &yogh;ere : of is kynedom
Þe kyng[on the margin.] kenulf deide : and to þe IoIe of heuene he com—
hit was afftur þat ore louerd : in his moder a-li&yogh;te
Ei&yogh;te hundret &yogh;er and Nyntene : bi a-countes ri&yogh;te.
¶ Seint kenelm, is &yogh;onge sone : In is seuenþe &yogh;ere
kyng was I-mad aftur him : al-þei he &yogh;ong child were.
his [o] soster Borewenild : louede him i-nou&yogh;
And in eche manere : to alle guod-nesse heo drou&yogh;.
Quendrith, þe oþur soster : of hire maneres nas nou&yogh;t,
For heo tornede to feolonie : and[orig. ant] to quede hire þou&yogh;t.
¶ heo i-sai&yogh; þat hire &yogh;ungue broþer : þat nas nou&yogh;t of seue &yogh;er,
kyng was i-mad of al þat lond : þat heore fader hadde er :
to him heo hadde gret onde : þat he scholde so riche beo
And eir of hire fader lond : and of more power þane heo;
heo þou&yogh;te, &yogh;if heo mi&yogh;te bringue : þis child of lijf-dawe,
Þat heo wolde of is heritage : beo quene with lawe.
Al hire þou&yogh;t was ni&yogh;t and day : to bi-þenche sum outrage,
Þat þis child were i-brou&yogh;t of dawe : for-to habbe is heritage.
heo porueide hire ri&yogh;t feolonliche : A poysun, strong i-nou&yogh;,
For-to &yogh;iue þis &yogh;ongue child : to slen him with wou&yogh;.
Þo þat poysun him was i-&yogh;iue : þat so strong and luþer was,
Ore louerdes mi&yogh;te was so muche : þat no-þe worse him nas.
Þo þe luþere quene þat i-sai : þat hit was al for nou&yogh;t,
Þat no poysun ne mi&yogh;te him sle : heo þou&yogh;te an oþur þou&yogh;t.
Þis &yogh;ongue child ane maister hadde : þat his wardein was—
Askebert he was i-cleoped : a strong trichour, alas!
For noman ne may to oþur : sonere tricherie do
Þane þilke þat is him euere nei&yogh; : and þat he trist mest to.
¶ Þis luþere quene bi-þou&yogh;te hire : of one false wrenche—
Men seith þat feolonie nas neuere non : þat womman ne can bi-þenche.
with þis Askebert heo spac : þis child to slen and spille;
heo bi-het him mede and guod i-nov&yogh; : and of eche þing don is wille.
So þat þis to luþere þingues : weren at one rede,
And bi-speken hou huy mi&yogh;ten best : don þe luþere dede.
Þe &yogh;wyle huy bi-speken boþe : þis &yogh;ongue child to quelle,
Þis swete sweuene þis child matte : þat ich ov wolle nouþe telle :
him þou&yogh;te þat þare stod a treo : ri&yogh;t bi-fore is bedde,
Þat a-non to þe steorrene it tilde : and swyþe wide it spradde;
Þis treo was fair and noble i-nov&yogh; : And schon wel bri&yogh;te and wide,
Ful of blostmene and of fruyt : and mani a riche bou&yogh; bi-side,
berninde wex and laumpes al-so : þicke brenninde and li&yogh;te—
So noble treo nas neuere i-sei&yogh;e : ne non þat schon so bri&yogh;te.
him þou&yogh;te he c[l]am[MS. cam] op-on þat treo : to þexte bowe an hei&yogh;
And bi-heold a-boute in-to al þe world : and a-perteliche[al. prute inou&yogh;] i-sei&yogh;.
Þe &yogh;wyle he stod opon þis treo : and bi-heold a-boute so,
him þou&yogh;te þat on of is nexte frend : and þat he truste mest to,
On þe grounde stod bi-neþe : and smot a-to þis treo,
Þat it feol a-doun to grounde : þat deol it was to seo.
to aluyte foul he[MS. ich] bi-cam : non fairore ne mi&yogh;te non[om. non] beo,
And bi-gan with Ioye i-nov&yogh; : ri&yogh;t into heouene fleo.
Þo þis child þou&yogh;te so : at wynchecombe he lay :
he a-wok and [in] grete þou&yogh;te was : boþe ni&yogh;t and day.
he nuste &yogh;wat tockninge it was : wel þe more was his[MS. hire] þou&yogh;t;
Are he þarof sum-þing wuste : bliþe nas he nou&yogh;t.
his norice, þat him hadde i-fed : and with hire milk forth i-brou&yogh;t,
Þat child heo louede euere muche : with dedes and with þou&yogh;t;
To hire þat child triste mest : —woluene hire name was :
Þis child tolde hire priueliche : of is metingue al is cas.
Þo þis Norice hadde i-heord : þe sweuene, þat was so guod,
heo bi-gan to siche sore : and in grete þou&yogh;te stod;
"Alas," heo seide, "þat ich scholde : euere þis day a-bide,
Þat mi child, mi swete heorte : swych cas schal bi-tide!
Alas, mi child, mi swete fode : þat ich habbe forth i-brou&yogh;t,
Þi soster, þat[al. om.] bi-spekez þi deth : to quelle þe heo hath i-þou&yogh;t.
Ake þe foul, þat þou bi-come to : and to heuene gan i-wende,
Þat was þi soule, þat þudere schal : aftur þi liues ende."—
Þis metyngue bi-cam soth i-nou&yogh; : þat he fond atþe laste.
For is soster and Askebert : bi-speken is deth wel faste.
Askebert seide a day : þat þis child scholde wende
An hontingue, to plei&yogh;en him : bi þe wodes ende,
And he with him, ase hit was ri&yogh;t : to witien him bi þe wei&yogh;e.
he[= heo, huy] wende to þe wode of clent : ase it were heom for-to pleie.
Ase huy wenden a-boute þe wode : ase ore louerd &yogh;af þe grace,
grete wille þat child hadde : þare to slepen in one place;
A-doun he lai wel soffteliche : and gan to slepe a-non.
Askebert ne þou&yogh;te nou&yogh;t : þat he scholde þannes gon.
bi-side in one derne stude : he gan to deluen faste
Ane put, &yogh;wane þat child were ded : þare-inne him to caste.
Þat child bi-gan a-wakien sone : ase þei it were bi cas,
After is maister he bi-heold : and ne sai&yogh; nou&yogh;t &yogh;ware he was.
Ake ore louerd him &yogh;af þe grace : þei he nuste nou&yogh;t of is dede,
Þat he spac to his maister : and þeos wordes sede :
"Þou trauailest," he seide, "a-boute nou&yogh;t : and þine &yogh;wyle þou dost spille,
For in ane oþure stude i schal deie : &yogh;ware hit is godes wille;
And þoru&yogh; tokningue of þis &yogh;eorde : þou schal wel i-seo
Þare[al. whane] al þi wille þou mi&yogh;t do : þat ich i-martred beo."
Forth wende þis luþere man : and þis child also.
huy comen to on oþur stude : þare þe dede was i-do.
Þis maister nam þe &yogh;eorde : and sette hire on þe grounde :
And heo bi-gan to leui þare : in wel luyte stounde,
And a swyþe gret Asch bi-cam sethþe : and &yogh;eot stant in þulke place,
to schewi þe mi&yogh;te of seint kenelm : and ore louerdes grace.
Þes luþere man nam þis child : in þe wode of klent
And ladde him, ase men doth a þeof : to a-fongue is Iuggement,
he ladde him into a priue stude : al out of þe wei&yogh;e,
bi-twene [twei][om.] hulles hei&yogh;e : into a deop ualeie.
¶ Þis child þoru&yogh; þe holi gost : þei þe oþur it nolde him telle,
Wuste wel is luþere þou&yogh;t : þat he him wolde a-quelle;
And þo he targede a luyte : þis luþere dede to done,
Þat child seide wel mildeliche : "&yogh;wy ne dost þou sone?"
he bi-gan Ane saume þat men singuth : in holie churche a-day,
Þat was "te deum laudamus" : are þat he a-doun lay.
Ri&yogh;t ase he scide an holi vers : þat þare-inne was and is,
A-latyn i-write, as alle þe oþure : and þe englisch so is þis
"Þe faire compaygnie of Martyrs : louerd, herieth þe :"
Ri&yogh;t ase he hadde þat fers i-seid : as þe boc tellez me,
Þe luþere man smot of is heued : onder an haw&yogh;þorn-treo,
Þare ase godes wille was : þat he i-martred scholde beo.
A coluere, &yogh;wi&yogh;t so eni milk : out of him gan teo
And ri&yogh;t euene heo was i-sei&yogh;e : into heouene fleo.
Onneþe he was seue &yogh;er old : are he i-martred were—
Alto soth is sweuene was : ase [men] mi&yogh;ten i-seo þere!
¶ Þis luþere man þat him a-slov&yogh; : bi-gan to delue faste
And made ane put, deop i-nou&yogh; : and þare-inne þis child caste;
he burede hit þare faste i-nou : þat he i-founde nere,
And wende hom a-&yogh;ein in is wei : and liet him ligge þere.
To Quendrith, his luþere soster : a-non-ri&yogh;t he gan i-wende
And tolde al þis luþere dede : hou he was i-brou&yogh;t to ende.
Þeos womman was þo glad i-nou&yogh;! : A-boute heo sende a-non
For-to saisi alle his londes to hire : and þe maneres euerech-on,
And liet hire makien quiene of þe Marche : ase hire broþur was king.
A schrewe lauedi heo was i-nov&yogh; : and wicke þoru&yogh; alle þing!
heo wende a-boute ope al hire lond : and nam hire manrede,[orig. manrade]
And bi-cam stuyrne and bi-ladde hire men : harde with muche wrech-hede.[al. 2 vv. more.]
heo liet hote into al þat lond : þat no man so wod nere
to nemmen hire broþer name : for loue ne for fere;
And &yogh;if man mi&yogh;te ani i-wite : þat nadde it nou&yogh;t bi-leued,
Þat he were sone i-nome : and i-smiten of is heued.
Þus fierde þis luþere womman : and sturede hire wel faste;
Þat no man ne dorste hire broþur bi-mene : huy weren so sore a-gaste.
And euere lai þis holie bodi : i-bured swiþe stille,
Þat no man ne dorste of him speke : a-&yogh;ein þe quiene wille.
So longue, þat he was al for-&yogh;ite : þo men ne moste of him speke.
Ake hit nas nou&yogh;t þat atþe laste : ore louerd him nolde a-wreke.
Þane no man nolde, þat witti was : of him þenchen ene,
Ore louerd nolde nou&yogh;t þat he were : allingues for-&yogh;ite so clene;
&YOGH;wane no man, þat witti was : of him ne hadde muynde,
A doumb best, þat is with-oute witte : hadde, a-&yogh;ein kuynde.
For a wydewe hadde ane &yogh;wite kov : þat wonede þare-bi-side,
Þat &yogh;eode a-dai to fetten hire mete : in þe wode wel wide
Þo seint kenelm was i-bured : in þe valeie þare doune.
Þis kou wolde eche daye : &yogh;wane heo come fram toune
to gaderi hire mete, with oþure kuyn : heo wolde gon al one
Fer a-doun into þis valeie : and hire felawes bi-leue ech-one,
And sitte bi þis holie bodi : al þe longue dai,
Ase it were for-to honouri him : for hit so one lay;
And so heo sat with-oute mete : al þe day to þen ende,
And &yogh;wane hit atþe eue was : hamward heo wolde wende.
&YOGH;wane heo cam hom at eue : fair and round heo was,
And swyþe Mielch al-so : —þat was a wonder cas!
For þare ne was no oþur kov : þat half so muche milk &yogh;eoue;
heo ne &yogh;af a-morewe noþe lasse : þei heo were i-milked an eue.[al. 2 vv. more.]
Folk þat þis wonder i-sai&yogh; : guode &yogh;eme alle huy nome
And a-waiteden wel a dai : &yogh;ware þe kou bi-come.
Heo seien hire sitte al þe day : in þe valeie þare doune,
Stille in one stude, meteles : for-to heo eode an eue to toune.
Ake &yogh;wi heo sete þare so : heo ne mi&yogh;ten i-wite noþing;
bote in heore heorte huy onder-stoden : þat it was sum tokning.
For þis kov wonede so þere : and adai drou&yogh; hire þare-to,
Þe ualeye men cleopeden "koubache" : and &yogh;eot men doth al-so.—
In kovbache þat holie bodi : lai wel mani a &yogh;er,
Þat men nusten of him no-þing : ase ich ov seide er :
For is soster, þat was so forth[al. fers : and] : in grete pruyte i-brou&yogh;t,
So gret þretningue for him heo made : þat men ne dorsten him nemme nou&yogh;t.—
Þo þis bodi ne moste beo : i-founde in Engelonde,
Ore louerd, þat wot alle þing : to him he sende is sonde.[al. þerto sette is honde]
Ase þe pope stod at rome : in his masse a day
At seint peteres weouede : ase muche folk þat i-sai,
A coluere, &yogh;wi&yogh;t so ani snov : cam fram heouene fleo
And leide on þe weuede a luyte writ : and sethþe a&yogh;en gan steo,
he flev&yogh; op into heouene an hei&yogh; : ase ore louerd it wolde.
Þat writ was &yogh;wijt and schon wel bri&yogh;te : þe lettres weren of golde.
Þe pope þonkede ihesu crist : and þat folk dude al-so.
he nam þe lettre on his hond : and þo heo was ondo,
he nuste &yogh;wat it was to segge : ne non in-si&yogh;t he ne couþe i-wite—
For he ne couþe englisch non : and on englis it was i-write.
he liet cleopie eche-manere men : of eche diuerse londe,
&yogh;if any covþe of þis holie writ : Ani-þing onder-stonde.
Þo weren þare men of Engelonde : þat wusten &yogh;wat it sede,
And onder-stoden wel þat writ : þo heo i-heorden it rede.
¶ Þat writ was puyr on Englisch i-write : ase men it radden þere;
And for-to tellen with-oute ryme : þeos wordes it were :
"In klent covbache kenelm, kyngues sone,[al. bern] lijth onder ane þorne, is[al. om.] heued him[al. om.] bi-reued."
Þis writ was wel nobleliche : i-wust and up i-do,
And i-holde for gret relike : and &yogh;eot it is al-so;
Þe nobleste relike it is on þar-of : þat is in þe churche of rome—
So it ou&yogh;te wel ho-so it under-stode : fram &yogh;wanne þat it come:
For &yogh;wane it out of heouene cam : fram ore louerdes honde,
&YOGH;wat noblere relike mi&yogh;te beo? : I-ne can non onder-stonde.
Þare-fore seint kenelmes day : ase þe pope makede is heste,
At rome huy holdez hei&yogh;liche : and makiez wel hei&yogh; feste.—
¶ Þe pope, þo he þe soþe wuste : þat it was swuch tockningue,
his messagers in-to Engelonde : he sende wit þis tiþingue;
To þe Erchebischope of kaunterburi : wolfred þat was þo,
his lettre he sende, þat he scholde : of swuche þingue onder-go
And seche after þe wode of klent : &yogh;if ani man mi&yogh;te i-wite,
And seche ane þorn in kovbache : ase it was in þe write,
And for-to seche þat holie bodi : þat derneliche lay þere,
And nimen it up with gret honour : þat hit i-schrined were.
Þo þe lettre fram þe pope : to þe Erchebischope cam,
Of bischopes and of clerkus : conseil þar-of he nam:
So þat in þe wode of klent : þat in wyricestre-schire is,
he liet seche þat holie bodi : and fond it out, i-wis,
Onder þe þorne at covbache : ase þat writ seide of rome.
For þe contreie-men bi-side : manie þudere huy come,[al. & for þe miracle of þe cou : þe what|loker þerto hi come.]
Þo[al. For] men of þare-bi-side : onder-&yogh;eten[al. þat o.] þat cas,
Ortreweden wel &yogh;ware it lay : for þe miracle so fair was.
A-non so þat bodi was op i-nome : þe &yogh;wile þat folk þare stod,
Þere sprong a welle, þare he lay : þat &yogh;eot is fair and guod.
A welle þare is cler i-nou&yogh; : and eucreft hath i-beo,
In þe stude þare he lai on : ase man mai þare i-seo,
Men[al. þat me] cleopieth "seint kenelmes welle"— : þat mani man hath i-sou&yogh;t,
And manie þoru&yogh; þe watere : of grete Anguisse beoth i-brou&yogh;t.
Of þe cite of wynchecumbe : and of þe contreie þare-bi-side
Þe men weren þat sou&yogh;ten so : þat holie bodi so wide:
And[al. for] þe bischopes hadden er i-loked : þat it scholde to winchecumbe beo i-bore
And i-schrined, þare is fader lai : þat a-rerde þat hous bi-fore.
Þis men nomen up þat holie bodi : þat of gloucestre-schire were,
And nobleliche toward wynchecumbe : with procession it bere.
Þat folk of wyricestre-schire : þat woneden þare-bi-side,
Nomen heom to rede manie : to maken þat bodi a-bide,
And sworen þat huy it wolden habbe : and noman ne scholde it heom bi-reue,
For in þe schire þare it i-founde was : huy seiden, it scholde bi-leue.
bi þe watere of pireford : þis two schirene hem mette,
And conteckeden for þis holie bodi : and faste to-gadere sette.
So þat huy nomen ane fourme of pays : to don bi[al. vp] godes grace,
&YOGH;if god heom wolde is wille sch[e]wen : are huy wenden fram þat place.
Feor huy weren i-trauailed and sore : so þat heom luste slepe ech-on:
huy maden ane fourme þat huy scholden alle : ligge slepe a-non,
And &yogh;weþur of þis twei schires : mi&yogh;ten sonore a-wake
huy scholden sauf i-nov&yogh; wenden forth : and þat bodi with hem[MS. him] take.
¶ Stille huy lei&yogh;en slepe faste : þis schirene boþe-to,
And resten heom of hore werienesse— : for ore louerd it wolde so.
[So] þat huy of gloucestre-schire : a-woken sone ech-on
At one tyme alle, ase god it wolde : and of wyricestre-schire nou&yogh;t on.
In pais huy wenden forth heore wey : and þis bodi with heom toke.
Wel fif mile wei huy weren i-wende : are þe oþere a-woke.
Þis oþere i-sei&yogh;en heom bi-gylede : anon so huy bi-gounne a-wake:
And siweden þis oþere swiþe faste : ake huy ne mi&yogh;ten heom nou&yogh;t of-take.—
Þis men toward wy[n]checombe : þat holie bodi huy bere.
Are heo mi&yogh;ten it þudere bringue : swyþe werie huy were.
So þat huy comen into one wode : a luyte bi este þe toune,
And resten heom, þo huy weren so nei&yogh; : op-on ane hei&yogh;e doune.
A-þurst huy weren for werienesse : so þat it nas non ende.
huy beden ore louerd for seint kenelmes loue : þat he scholde heom drinke sende.
A fair welle þare sprong op : an hei&yogh; op-on þe doune—
Þat &yogh;uyt is þare, cler and cold : half a mile fram toune;
heo is nouþe wel faire i-heoled : with freo ston, ase ri&yogh;t is,
I-redi ech man to drinken of : þat cometh þare-forth, i-wis.
¶ Þe Monekes of Wynchecombe : arerd habbez þare-bi-side
A fair chapele of seint kenelm : þat men sechez ful wide.—
Quendrith, þe luþere womman : at wynchecumbe þo was;
bote heo nuste nou&yogh;t hire broþer so nei&yogh; : ne no-wi&yogh;t of þat cas.
In seint peteres churche heo sat : bi-side þe Abbeie-&yogh;ate,
In a soler inþe est-side : and lokede out þare-ate.
heo i-sai&yogh; al þis grete folk come : a-doneward of þe doune hei&yogh;e
Toward wynchecumbe : a-luyte fram suyd-lei&yogh;e.
heo Axede &yogh;wat men it weren : and &yogh;wat huy þou&yogh;ten þere.
Men seiden þat huy to churche wolden : and þat huy hire broþer bere.
Þo was þis Quiene sori i-nov&yogh;! : in grete deole and fere
hire sauter heo nam on honde : ase þei heo witles were.
Of þe sauter þe laste saume : bi-fore þe Euesongus, i-wis,
of corsingue and[al. om.] of luþere men : and of mansingue i-maked heo is:
"Deus laudem" [heo] is i-cleoped. : þis saume þe Quiene radde,
For-to a-corsi hire broþur bodi : and alle þat him þudere ladde.
Þo heo cam to þe Ninteoþe vers : ase þe mansingue endez, i-wis,
Þat "hoc opus eorum" : a-latin i-cleoped it is,
Þat seit þat[al. what] men it beo scholden : þat duden[al. afongeþ] þat ilke dede:
Opon hire owene heued it cam : ase heo þat vers gan rede:
For ri&yogh;t ase heo þat vers radde : out-borsten boþe hire ei&yogh;e
And fullen a-doun op-on hire sauter : ase manie men i-sei&yogh;e.[al. 2 vv. more.]
Þe sauter is &yogh;uyt at wynchecombe : and ho-so come wole þare-to,
Aperteliche man may þare i-se : &yogh;ware þe dede was i-do.—[al. 2 vv. more.]
Þis holie bodi was forth i-bore : with gret honour ate fine,
And in þe Abbeie, þare he lijth &yogh;uyt : i-don in wel noble schrine.
Þis luþere Quiene deide sethþe : in schrewedenesse i-nou&yogh;;
Þat bodi, ase a corsede wrechche : into ane diche man it drov&yogh;,
Into þe fouleste þat was þare a-boute : and þare-inne man it slong—
bote hire endingue sunful[al. scenfol] were : me þinchez elles it hadde i-beo wrong!
Nov god for þe loue of seint kenelm : is swete grace vs[MS. it] sende,
Þat we moten to þulke Ioie : þare he is inne,i-wiende. AmeN.
